My bet are A & D:
A - One VPN to the On Prem Site, and a VPC Peering between both VPC in US-West-1. We do not peer VPC with VPN (this is why I exclude D).
C - VTGW of course.
C & D , agree with Rabbit117

questions.question_text: A customer is running a software-defined data center (SDDC) in the US-West-1 region and wants to connect the workload network segment to their on-premises data center and their company Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) running in US-West-1. Which two supported connectivity options can they use to accomplish this? (Choose two.)

choices.A: One virtual private network (VPN) and one VPC Peering

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
This is a L2VPN definition

Selected Answer: B
+1 for BBB
I agree with amitt8 - B is my answer if we want to go with same broadcast domain

Selected Answer: B
If you have a compatible version of NSX-T installed in your on-premises data center, you can use your existing NSX Edge appliance as the on-premises (client) side of an L2VPN that connects to your SDDC. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vmc-aws-networking-security/GUID-ACC0D32B-F8A6-4D64-84C2-B3CF72508507.html

comments.content: Or If necessary, you can download and deploy a standalone NSX Edge to use as the L2VPN client. The following table lists compatible SDDC and on-premises versions.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I agree with amit88, is B â€”> https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.2/administration/GUID-BE8A3D3C-5E0D-4777-B4F4-908E64FCB771.html

Selected Answer: B
I agree with amit88, B will provide a single broadcast domain.
B Will be the choice if we want to go with same broadcast domain. But For Non NSX we need to deploy Autonomous edge Node!

The on-premises environment is NOT using NSX today; however, the administrator wants to avoid having to change IP addresses after each migration, and there are some applications that require the same broadcast domain. Which connection is needed to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:

questions.question_text: What are three valid migration modes in VMware HCX? (Choose three.)

An administrator deploys a normal (non-stretched) cluster of six i3en.metal hosts in VMware Cloud on AWS. When deploying virtual machines to this cluster, which two of the listed storage policies would satisfy the service-level agreement (SLA) for a six host cluster? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Failure to tolerate = 1 failure - RAID-5 (erasure coding)
choices.D: Failure to tolerate = 2 failures - RAID-6 (erasure coding)
choices.B: Site disaster tolerance = Dual Site Mirroring

discussion.content:
I don't believe D & E are correct. E is a basic policy name. D is correct though. Cite:

This document explains the actual SLA requirements, for 2-5 hosts or in this question, 6 hosts which requires FTT-2.
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/support/vmw-cloud-aws-service-level-agreement.pdf

And based on this document, I think the answer section is actually missing an option, of RAID1 with an FTT of 2. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vsphere.vmc-aws-manage-data-center-vms.doc/GUID-EDBB551B-51B0-421B-9C44-6ECB66ED660B.html

So again, I think we're actually missing an option. Any answer has to have FTT2 to meet the SLA's and E is not a valid answer. It's the name of a policy with a blank name.
D & E are Correct

Selected Answer: DE
Clusters containing three to five hosts use 1 failure - RAID-1 (Mirroring). 
Clusters containing six or more hosts use 2 failures - RAID-6 (Erasure Coding).
The VMC Workload Storage Policy -<cluster name> will be changed from 1 failure to 2 failures if the number of hosts change to 6 or more.
See section "VMware Cloud on AWS Managed Storage Policy Profiles" at the link below.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-on-AWS/services/com.vmware.vsphere.vmc-aws-manage-data-center-vms.doc/GUID-EDBB551B-51B0-421B-9C44-6ECB66ED660B.html

Selected Answer: DE
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/managed-storage-policy-profiles#_Toc62466922
